post.message: If anyone's interested in how the LINQ in JavaScript implementation using generators I blogged about how it works - http://www.aaron-powell.com...

My personal website (http://lee-phillips.org/) has a few dynamic bits, such as a randomly selected quotation, but most of the content is statically generated and simply rsynced to the server, similar to your setup. I've been Slashdotted and HNed a few times with no impact on the server performance - and the server hardware is quite modest. I wrote a Python program to generate the site; this program has grown to 3000 lines, but it does a lot of things for me. It collects information and places it in different places on the website, it can notify Twitter of new content, it makes an Atom feed, it turns some articles into LaTeX source, generates Amazon affiliate links based on the content on the page, builds a file that I can turn into a graphviz picture of all my content, handles references and bibliographies, etc. It's a perennial work in progress that I hope one day to pound into a form that other people might be able to use, and release as free software.
Yeah I looked into this a year ago and thought it was a novel solution. That said the shift to annotations in v2 I'm not so keen on.
Thanks
Thanks!
Why such a copy-paste with ternary operator? Would be much DRYer if you define `condition` variable, set it in `switch`, then have single ternary operator.
Thank you very much for your feedback, Eugene! Your point is absolutely valid, therefore I changed the code and updated the post.
cool :)
https://github.com/danharpe...
Thanx, really great project.

Basically is well known that finally block is always executed. So if something is wrong in that example is that return in try block. But a good practice is not to use return in finally block as it purpose is to clean up if something when wrong in try clause.

Hey Damian,

thank you for your comment. It was also my intent to show, that it is a bad habit to use return statement in both the try and in the finally blocks.

I really think it's better to avoid return statemets at all in finally blocks.

In a package.json you can specify scripts, for example on the 'postinstall' hook, this is a non-npm script written by the package author, and thus potentially unsafe. What npm does before executing those scripts, is 'downgrade' permissions to the current user. So your 'sudo' is actually only applied to the tasks npm does, not the pre-/postinstall scripts from the package author.
very useful, thank you for sharing
Protip: just use https://github.com/sindreso... -- much easier.
brilliant

This is extremely useful, thanks for writing it.

I hate go be the bearer of bad news though but there is a small overlooked similar issue I only just noticed. I'm reading this article on my phone and the map caught me on the way down. A similar snipper is needed for touchmove events ;)
Oh, thanks. You are right. This or a similar approach could also be done for touch events. I'll try to update the article.

S'alright! I've been caught so many times by maps on peoples' pages that it just seemed so perfect that the one time where the problem wasn't going to catch me even if it wasn't solved, there should be another problem lurking.

All the code which calls our daw() functions

you mean draw() :)
Oh, of course. Thanks.

Hi Adam, thank you for writing this, it's very useful!

I wonder, on the UX side, if that behavior would be intuitive for the user. Your approach is obviously degrees of magnitude better than the current Google Maps quirk, where the scroll is all over the place. I think this is one of those cases where a usability quirk becomes the expected behavior by the user.

Also, I don't know if you're running into the same issue, but for me it only triggers inside scrolling when doing a complete, full click. If I drag a part of a map, the inside scroll is not enabled. Is that a bug or did you mean to only enable inside scrolling when doing a simple click?

I think sometimes, if you start scrolling really fast while the map is zooming, the event propagates and you lose focus of the map and start scrolling on the body. That's probably related to the state of the map while the map is zooming.

Thank you!

Antonio

Hi Antonio,

thank you for your comment. I updated the article right now. It will not wait for a full click anymore, just dragging the map is going to be enough. My function was listening for the click event, but now it is listening for the 'mousedown' event.

I couldn't reproduce the other issue with "scrolling really fast". Can you please tell me, what browser do you use?

Thanks.
Have you guys got any performance data on different browsers / os / platforms?
What kind of performance data are you thinking of?
I'm using WordPress and would like to use this functionality. I use maps across many pages. Where should I copy this? functions.php?
Good job, Adam! Thanks. =]

is posible disable link to default markers are on the map?
thanks
Great technique of usability!

Hi, I prefer the following technique which doesn't require users to learn new behaviors.
- disable the map zooming when you start scrolling from out of the map
- reactivate it after scroll ended to be able to zoom on the map without other interaction (like clicking)


var scrollTimer

$(window).scroll(function() {
  map.setOptions({ scrollwheel: false })
  clearInterval(scrollTimer) if scrollTimer
  scrollTimer = setTimeout(function() {
    map.setOptions({ scrollwheel: true })
  }, 100)
});
Sorry where I need to add in the mapmarker.jquery.fj file this code? thanks
what about scrolling via touch?
Saving fonts into localstorage.. whaaat!? Fonts are cached by the browser just like any other resource, and the download of fonts is not blocking. Can you elaborate more on why you did the above?

Hi Jack, thanks for your comment.

I updated the article to better show, what kind of difference it makes. I added 4 links where you can try it out, and take a look a the score at Google Page Speed Insights.

http://bdadam.com/blog/load...

There are two things:
- loading CSS is per default blocking
- when using a webfont, the browser renders the rest of the page, but until the font has loaded, it displays a blank space in place of the text that uses the font. (most browsers, except Firefox) - see https://developers.google.c...

For the users it is a much better experience, when the browser doesn't wait for the font files being downloaded. They get their content much faster. Worst case scenario is, when font files take long to download. In this case, users get the page rendered with a fallback font first which gets replaced once the font has finished loading.

Thanks for sharing. :)

Unless I'm mistaken, the one thing you achieve with the localStorage technique is bypassing the browser's use of invisible text (for up to 3 seconds in recent browsers and up to forever in older browsers) on first loads.

A comparable test case would be a link to the my-base64-fonts.woff.css stylesheet in the head:
1. First page load may have invisible text.
2. Second page load will use the browser cache and apply the fonts almost instantly.

Are there additional benefits to your localStorage technique beyond making sure the text is visible (with FOUT) as early as possible on the first page load?

(On http://bdadam.com/samples/w... the bold font doesn't show on Firefox 34/Windows. That's probably a Firefox bug.)

By the way, earlier this year I tried something a bit similar but only caching the stylesheet's URL (because I'm using Typekit and wanted to speed it up). It's probably a flawed technique but
here's my write-up: http://fvsch.com/code/typek...
The bold characters in async version display as normal in IE, and Opera 12.

Thanks for your comment!

Actually with the localStorage technique you achieve more than that:

1. As you mentioned, (text)content is getting rendered as soon as possible. The browser doesn't have to block and wait for the stylesheet with fonts in it to load. -> better user experience on first visit

2. If you in your test case loaded the "my-base64-fonts.woff.css" asynchronously, then you would end up with FOUT on every request, not just on the first one.

3. Your font files are really only loaded once -> not even a HEAD request is getting sent on later visits -> better UX on subsequent visits on slow connections
(even if you set a very long "expires" header, browsers tend to send a HEAD request to check for changes on later visits, or for example when pressing F5)

The costs:
- FOUT can happen on first visit (which would not happen with blocking requests)
- localStorage is maybe be less performant than browser cache (I haven't really measured it. On my laptop it only took 4ms to load the fonts. Maybe I'll do some research on it later.)

Also thanks for telling me about FF34. I checked it with FF35 and seems to be fine. But I will do some more investigation. What about this article? Can you see the bold headings here?
Could you please tell me which IE version? IE11 seems to be fine, but I'm going to do some more investigation.
Very cool man, I going to implement this from now on, thanks!

Hi Sebastien,

it is a very good idea, I really like it. Thanks for sharing it.

I think it can work very well on smaller maps. But, I guess, on larger maps (30-50% of the screen) it is much harder for users to initiate the scroll outside the map area.

It would be worth to test it. Have you ever run user tests with this method?

Can't see any bold type on this page. Using FF32.

BTW.

Guys, FF34? 35? What are you talking about? I've just checked on mozilla and the latest one is FF32. Where did you get the 34 or 5? Nightly builds? I've also checked on Can I Use (http://caniuse.com/#search=... and they are telling that 32 is current and 35 is used by 0.01% of people in world.

Ok so I've checked in Chrome 37 (not the latest) and there are no bold fonts on this page nor on the async test. I've also checked the HTML for any imports or calls for Open Sans Pro but I could find only FontAwessome icon font. No base64, no import, urls, srcs or anything.
Oh, I've just though of something. Can you uninstall Source Sans Pro from your PC, refresh the page with ctrl+f5 and see if you see what we see?

Right now: Fx32 is stable, Fx33 is Beta, Fx34 is Aurora and Fx35 is Nightly.

Some people use those advanced releases for a number of reasons: if you develop stuff in Firefox, if you want to check out early web platform features, or if you want to help finding bugs (so that they can hopefully be fixed before the related code lands in a stable release). See: https://www.mozilla.org/en-...

Chrome as something similar with Chrome Canary. (I suspect the name refers to canary birds who were used in coal mines to detect when the air was toxic. Canary birds die way sooner than humans do from carbon monoxyde intoxication. So Chrome Canary is the browser that may die easily, so that Chrome stable may survive.)

Re. your #2: I actually tested adding a <link rel="stylesheet" href="typekit_css_url_saved_in_localstorage"> to the head with an inlined script checking localStorage in the head. There was no FOUT with this technique in Chrome and Firefox. Safari had a micro-FOUT on some of the page loads (it's the same effect as the video in my post, but it wouldn't happen every time in Safari with the localStorage technique).

It was an interesting solution but not perfect in Safari, so I switched to a PHP session variable for storing the URL, and writing the <link rel="stylesheet"> in PHP so that browsers can see it even sooner.

Thanks for pointing out #3, I hadn't thought about it.

I can confirm the "no bold font" problem on my setup in:
- Win7 + Firefox 34
- Win7 + IE 11
But it does work on Win7 with Chrome (stable and Canary).

Also in Firefox I can confirm that the CSS code is saved in localStorage and used. It appears on the Style Editor pane and seems to be complete. If I edit even some whitespace in the (live) stylesheet, Firefox/devtools reload it and the bold font is displayed.

Here's a wild guess: maybe some browsers will only read the first 65536 bytes of CSS when you set the textContent of a style element?
Your fonts stylesheet is 70531 bytes. The 65536 limit would end up in the middle of the second font declaration, which would then be dropped.
Ways to test this idea:
- invert the two fonts (bold first, normal after);
- put each font into its own style element.
Just a wild guess. :)

Thank you, your comment helped me to solve this bug - I hope. :) It was a tricky one.

The problem was: in the CSS I declared "local('Source Sans Pro')" for both the regular and the semibold font-face. Which led to this problem, when somebody had already installed Source Sans Pro on their computer. Now it's fixed with "local('Source Sans Pro Semibold')" for the semibold fonts.

Thanks for your help. The comment from Krzysiek Płaneta led me to the solution - I hope.

The problem was: in the CSS I declared "local('Source Sans Pro')" for both the regular and the semibold font-face. Which led to this problem, when somebody had already installed Source Sans Pro on their computer. Now it's fixed with "local('Source Sans Pro Semibold')" for the semibold fonts.
It's also an interesting solution. So you mean you didn't even load that Typekit script on the second page load?

What do you do when you have seperate files for lite/regular/bold versions of the same font and you just want to use one font-name in the CSS-files, so you avoid using "Fontname-bold" when you need to use bold characters...?

Hi Kim, actually this is also the case with Source Sans Pro. When you declare font-faces you can provide more data about font-weight and font-style. Take a look at this example:

@font-face{font-family:Source Sans Pro;font-weight:400;font-style:normal;src:local("Source Sans Pro"),url(font-data-of-the-regular-font)}

@font-face{font-family:Source Sans Pro;font-weight:600;font-style:normal;src:local("Source Sans Pro Semibold"),url(font-data-of-the-semibold-font)}

Please note the difference in "font-weight" and also in "src". For italic variants you would use "font-style:italic;".

Yep, for a given session I only load the script once. I figure if the script detects browser support and generates a URL to a stylesheet that works for that browser, why run the script more than once? :)
It's a bit hackish and I've seen issues on Android for instance. But it's fun to experiment.
Yeah, of course great experiment. :) What kind of issues did you have on Android?
I'm loving what I've seen thus far, but was wondering if it would be detrimental to simply include the JS in a concatenated file in the footer. I'm a "one JavaScript file to rule them all" kinda guy.

Hi Kyle, "one JavaScript file to rule them all" is a very good thing, but it would shoot you in the foot this time. It would cause flashing on every page load, because the text would be rendered with the fallback fonts first and then it would get replaced by the webfonts.

Therefore the script has to stay inline, in the head, over any link[rel=stylesheet] declarations. It also should be minified/uglified.

I can't recall the source, but iirc there is no benefit in gzipping your inline-font stylesheets - they may be 100-300kbs, but the files are already compressed, so all you're doing is adding processing overhead on both your server (to encode) and client (to decode). It's worth testing to see if there is a true benefit.

What you mean is maybe the font files (.woff) itself, because they are already binary and compressed.
But it's not true for the CSS files which contain the woff files as base64 encoded strings.

In this case with Open Sans Pro (regular and semibold) this looks like:
Two woff files -> 2 * 26kb = 52kb (gzipping doesn't have any significant effect)
Base64 encoded CSS file -> 69kb
Gzipped CSS file -> 53kb

It's almost always woth to gzip text content. It's just the binary and well compressed content which isn't woth gzipping.
Ah yes, you're absolutely right. Thanks for clearing that up.

It seems you should swap these two lines around so you append the element to the dom before injecting the content. Otherwise IE 9 will fail.

document.head.appendChild(style);
style.textContent = localStorage.sourceSansPro;

Thank you, I didn't know about this issue. I don't have native IE9, only IE11 with IE9 mode. I couldn't see any problems. I also tried webpagetest.org with IE9, but didn't find anything suspicious on the screenshots.

Do you maybe have some more info about this issue? I can't seem to find anything.

No. I just tried creating the element beforehand after reading this post.

http://stackoverflow.com/qu...

I've tried my solution in IE 9 and 10 on VMFusion (with win 7 and 8 I think - We didn't do the tests on my machine) and it seems to work just fine.

http://kimblim.dk/test/webf...

Tip: use VirtualBox with virtual drives from Modern.ie: https://www.modern.ie/en-us...

Use native browsers or just IE10 that simulates more correctly.
Awesome. That's what I had assumed, but thanks for the insight. :)

Thanks for the tip. I also use the VMs from modern.ie.

Actually I don't really prefer using IE10, because it has the smallest user base on my websites, and it is also not perfect when emulating IE8/9. So I use IE11 which can emulate IE10 quite well. I have a VM for IE9 which can also emulate IE8. Thankfully I haven't have a project in a while where I had to really support IE8.

I also believe in progressive enhacement, so that if nothing works (in IE8), the browser can still parse and render the HTML. Even if it looks funny, the content should be readable.
Awesome technique and tips. Would be great to add a list of webfont foundries that allow you to licence self hosted webfonts.

Hi Mark, thanks for the compliments. :)

It's actually a good idea with the list of open fonts. What I can surely say, is that all the fonts on Google Fonts can be legally downloaded and self hosted, because they are all "open source" fonts. Terms: https://www.google.com/font...

Font directory: https://code.google.com/p/g...
And it will break a little on textarea width change which could be caused in real life by let's screen orientation change.
I'll start collecting a list here https://delicious.com/mark....

Even with the delay from localstorage only being 50-100ms there's a perceivable re-render as the page loads. Could you tweak the script to hide text till localstorage has been checked, then add the font and make text visible. I'm happy to wait 100ms if the page feels more stable as it loads. Then if it's not in localstorage show the text immediately and async in the font file with a fout.
Something like this where you can tune the amount of delay you want to allow the browser to parse the stylesheet. http://markzeman.com/fonts/...
Thanks, it's a very good point. I updated the code and the demo a little bit. I added an onresize event handler. This should solve the problem.

Nice writeup! Thanks.
What about WOFF2? How could we implement WOFF2 fonts and WOFF2 capable browsers?

Is there a (Modernizr-) check we could use to switch the stylesheets?

Interesting technique, although one factor to bear in mind is that you have a high chance of a cache hit (even on the first request) if you serve the font from an external provider such as Google Fonts. This is especially true if you use one of the most popular web fonts such as Open sans.

Great thread. Thanks for all the research and experimentation, all.

By the way, FF33 is now latest stable.

Good point about the cache hit, but I think it's still a minority of users who have your in the cache. It really depends on the visitors and what kind of other sites they also visit. But for those, who don't have the fonts in the cache, it's still going to be a performance penalty to use Google Fonts.

It would be interesting to test it, how many users do have those fonts in the cache. I haven't found any statistics regarding this question. My gut feeling says way below 50%.

It's actually a very good idea. It could improve this solution. I found this simple check from Filament Group: https://github.com/filament...

We only have to provide two different CSS files and load one or the other based on this feature detection. The rest of technique stays almost the same.

Thank you! I will update the article in the next few days.

Actually on your page, the script is placed incorrectly. It should be placed into the HEAD above all the <link rel="stylesheet" href=""> tags. You can see that rerendering, because your text first gets rendered in the default font and then rerendered when the script at the end of the page gets executed. It will always cause rerendering.

If you put the script into the HEAD you won't notice any re-render, because loading from localStorage is blocking.

I also measured how long it takes to load the font from localStorage. On my laptop it took around 4-6ms. On my Nexus 4 it needed some more time, about 20-60ms, mostly below 40ms. So yeah, there is no free lunch.

Google Fonts API uses fonts from a central location, so once a font is downloaded for the first website that uses the font (and takes the latency hit) then __ALL__ subsequent websites have 0 font file latency for 1 year, because the font files are cached for 1 year. The CSS served by Google Fonts API is cached for 1 day, so that when an update is made, your users see the new font within a day.
Sorry, but i dont really get why is localStorage different than the browser cache?
Because you can directly read/write/check localStorage, but you can't do it with browser cache. Browser cache can only be read by the browser.
yup, that goes without saying. this seems like you are rebuilding a feature, which is already native to browsers and works perfectly.

No. I'm using a feature which is missing from the native browser cache, but can be "polyfilled" with localStorage.

For this technique to work, you need to be able to check, whether the resource is present or not. If you can't check, you cannot act. If you do not act, you degrade performance. If you need good performance and also need webfonts, then you have to use a trick like this.
Agree about "class"; ES6 is still a prototype-based language and the "class" keyword is again the language pretending to be something that it is not. (just like the "new" operator).

Typo "Douglas Cropckford" - should be "Crockford" :P
Thanks for the tl;dwatch article!
Even with a cache lifetime of a year there's no guarantee that the font file will stay in cache, as depending on how frequently it's used a browser is likely to eject it so it can cache other content
Thanks for your comment. :) I fixed the typo.

That's true. But to Dave's point, it only takes *a* site to take one for the team (i.e., any subsequent website). This solution - as brilliant as it is - requires each member of the team to implement it. That's a lot of time in aggregate, yes?

Again, love the solution. But the bigger question is, when are browsers going to become more responsible for what should be their responsibilities? Why must we contort (?) to do what just makes sense?
Lambdas are popular because of Javascript? You are kidding right? :)
Where did you use them before you knew JavaScript?

I'm not sure I agree that "it only takes *a* site to take one for the team" as there's no guarantee that once a font is downloaded how long it will stay in the cache - we're building sites that consume more and more cache, and using many different fonts from many different foundries.

Not sure I follow the bigger question of when browsers are going to become more responsible - originally browsers didn't block waiting for the font and display the page anyway until we (devs and designers) complained we didn't like the experience it gave our visitors, so instead they started waiting for font.

Ilya's got an interesting proposal to allow us to have greater level of control, but we'll still have a challenge when we choose to use a font - https://github.com/igrigori...

I already have a main .css file where I do my @font-face declarations. CSS may be blocking, but the font-face declaration is a small part of a CSS file that's needed anyway, and the fonts are downloaded asynchronously and cached nevertheless. How is this technique better?
I don't use JS at all. I have used it in Erlang and LISP and also in Ruby. Why?

Fair enough. It's not guaranteed. But again, given the alternative, 1 site vs n individually implemented solutions, 1 (with some risk) feels - sans a massive high traffic site - reasonable.

re: responsibility.

For example, as you mentioned, there's no guarantee. But shouldn't there be? Why can't the number of native browser fonts be expanded? Why can't the browser pre-cache say jquery, Bootstraps and at least a handful of more common "stuff". The idea that each individual site has to presume nothing and fend for itself - when that's not really as true as it used to be - feels dated.

I'm suggesting that given how things have changed, we all recognize that, the browser's role and responsibilities be adjusted / updated, or at least discussed. Why so many hacks (?) for what feels like should be common browser sense at this point?

I was just wondering, whether you used a language before JS, which was also popular enough to make lambda expression popular.

For me it was really the case, that I first met with lambda expressions in JavaScript many many years ago. Then it was easy to understand them when I later got to them in Python or C#. The "lambda syntax" in JS used to be not that simple as in ES6/Python/C#, but the concept is totally the same.

So I can totally confirm, that JS introduced me the lambdas and made me like them.
Same for me. Also, Ruby only got lambda functions a few years ago, in the version 1.9, despite of being super famous in the recent years with the startups boom. So, JS is the king :)

Oh, now I see. But in this case the expiration header doesn't matter, because the font is stored in localStorage. If it gets downloaded once, it "stays in cache" as long as the browser can store it.

I was referring to rendering block and blank spaces. It's only an issue for the first time the user visit the site, otherwise the cache kicks in and it should work like a charm, shouldn't it?
It grind my gear re-inventing browser caching just for one single request... Isn't the async request sufficient to avoid perfomance issues the first time? What's the actual role of localStorage in lieu of browser HTTP caching?

I stumbled upon something interesting while implementing this technique: iOS Safari in private browsing mode disables localStorage! You can't add to it. It's rather unique in this behavior. Desktop Safari doesn't do this. Android browsers don't do it either.

Anyway, it's an unusual edge case and as the code is set up they'll just be stuck with the default font. Although in my particular case I threw a check in so that if I get an error while trying to store the font into localStorage, it still loads the stylesheet into the DOM.

This technique is optimizing mostly the first request, but this is one of your most important requests. If your site doesn't load fast, the user bounces. As a side effect also the subsequent visits get optimized, because you can spare those HEAD requests and many TCP roundtrips.

Actually it's not always one request. It's one request per font file and one more CSS request in case of Google Fonts.

Thanks for your comment. Actually I already thought about this case, but you are right, the code in its current state doesn't work properly. This also happens if you disable cookies.

The good thing is, with a little refactoring, those browser will fall back to loading the fonts every time, which is not that bad either, because we have browser caching as a fallback.

The words are harsh and the intention is unclear. Just slow down, chew on things, digest them fully, the come back when you're feeling less shouty.

My arguments are honest. I am not going to sugarcoat the truth Adrian. Crockford has definitely made a few great contributions to Javascript, but he has got to stop acting like he is the only one. There is a universal effort to improve Javascript, especially from the likes of Google and Facebook. It is evident that Javascript is heading in the direction it needs too (at the behest of Crockford) and perhaps maybe Douglas just needs to move on and let those who want to see Javascript become a decent language do so. Seems he is used to being the golden child, pinup poster boy of Javascript, but every day his arguments get even crazier. He needs to step back and stop tainting his reputation and great legacy.

As for your transpiler remark. I am aware of what a transpiler does, but everyone knows a transpiler is a hack for the sake of backwards compatibility. I am not talking about transpiling ES6 to ES5 for example, I was talking about the fact people keep trying to redesign Javascript and make it into the next C++, when it isn't needed. The current syntax works, it just needs to be cleaned up a little and standardised. And yes, until support matures, we will use transpilers. I will not use a transpiler however to "Convert X super hyped variant subset of Javascript" to "Vanilla Javascript"

Isn't this a good use case for ServiceWorker?
Thanks, Jeremy. It's a good odea. I will take a look at it. ServiceWorker seems to be a valid alternative once browser support gets better.
Could you use the application cache manifest instead of local storage to remove the need for JavaScript?

It's a very interesting idea, Christopher. But I don't think you can use applicationCache instead of localStorage, because it doesn't have a cross-browser method to check whether an item is in the cache or not (atm. Firefox only).

Completely getting rid of JavaScript doesn't seem to be possible either, because you have to provide different font loading methods for the first time visit (empty cache) and for a returning visit (font is already cached). Getting rid of JavaScript means this has to be done on the server side, where you can't check the browser cache.

I have to say I see more potential in the ServiceWorker. As soon as I get around to it I will take another look at both the appcache and the ServiceWorker.

Hey Adam,

Cool beans man, just throwing it out there... The thing with the application cache is that it would simply load the resource per normal the first time it's requested and then it'll load from the cache each subsequent time which _should be_ quicker IMO than crunching JS to pull from local storage. I could be wrong though.

Another option is the file-system API which would allow you to store the *.woff file in a virtual file-system instead of local storage; of course you'll have to check compatibility to see if it'll work for your target audience, but that goes without saying. The interface just seemed more conducive to storing a file locally than local storage. I might try throwing together a quick demo with the application cache and see if it works as I expect it to. I'll let you know either way =D

Thanks for your post, interesting topic!

If I'm using Lato for body would it be advisable to convert all of these to css?
Lato
Lato Italic
Lato Bold

How would this work in the function?

latoregular, latoitalic, latobold, latobold_italic

Thanks for your compliment. :)

You should convert "Lato" and "Lato Bold" at least. Browsers can render italic fonts based on the base font, if there is no specific italic font. If you are satisfied with the results, then it's fine. If not, then you also have to include the Italic ones too.

I recommend that you put all the font files into the same CSS file. For more details you can take a look at the followup article here: http://bdadam.com/blog/bett...

Methods 2 and 2.5 can fail to return any documents in smaller collections since you may not have any records with random fields greater than the generated random number. Is there a good solution for this? I'd like to stay away from skip since the server still has to walk all those records.

Update: I'm randomizing by adding geospatial data to each document and then using a randomized $near query. Not sure the performance implications of this, but it is guaranteed to return a document each time.

That's actually a very clever idea, Devon. Thanks for sharing.
I don't know the performance implications either, but you could run a little benchmark, if you had some time. I would be interested.

I also found this StackOverflow question: http://stackoverflow.com/qu...

One answer suggests that you make two queries, one with $gte and one with $lte. The other answer also suggest using $near with setting one coordinate to 0.
with a lot of text, things get jumpy

Thanks, Adam! I benchmarked the geospatial randomization against your methods and it performed MUCH worse. Way moreso than I expected.

Method 1: 1.981s

Method 2: 1.62s

Method 2.5: 1.533s

Geospatial: 770.667 seconds

Maybe it's my implementation that's the problem. I added this to each document:

randomizer: {
type: "Point",
coordinates: [Math.floor(Math.random() * 90), 0]
}

Created an index:
db.test.ensureIndex({"randomizer": "2dsphere"});

Then, I added this test:

while (i) {
var query = {
randomizer: {
$near: {
$geometry: {
type: "Point",
coordinates: [Math.floor(Math.random() * 90), 0]
}
}
}
};
var randomElement = db.test.findOne(query);
i--;
}
Changing the index to a 2d index rather than a 2dsphere improved the result by about 40 seconds.
Thanks for doing the benchmarks and sharing the results, Devon. It's quite sad, that this query doesn't perform better. :( I really liked the idea.

Actually I haven't tested it with very long texts before, but you seem to be right. It slowed down the browser when I pasted the text of a longer article many times.

Sorry, but this is a bit of a dumb question... But, what are the steps to add the WOFF2 fonts to our server? Do we need to add it to a file on the server and then which parts in the script (above) do we amend with our details e.g. paths, etc...?

Hey Andrew, you have to embed the font files into some CSS files with base64 encoding. Then you call the loadFont function. The parameters are paths pointing to your CSS files. So you don't serve the woff files directly, but encode them into css.

Call the function like this:

loadFont('sourceSansPro', '/static/article-assets/webfonts2/fonts.woff.css', '/static/article-assets/webfonts2/fonts.woff2.css')

For embedding the woff files in CSS you can find an example in the code repository:

https://github.com/bdadam/O...

I hope this helps you.

Hey fellah, nice solution.

Have you considered using the FontFace API directly to fetch the font instead of XMLHttpRequest?
It's asynchronous and doesn't have the extra bloat of base64 encoding.

function getFont(fontName, url, func) {

var f = new FontFace(fontName, "url(" + url + ")", {});
f.load().then(function (loadedFace) {

document.fonts.add(loadedFace);

// put loadeFace into local storage here.

if (func) {func();}

});

}

I'm using a very similar technique to yours but I split off early if woff2 is supported and use the API instead.

"He also stopped using null, because it doesn't make any sense to have two kinds of undefined: null and undefined." It's not good practice to set variable to "undefined". It's breaking JavaScript paradigm. Actually undefined and null have different meanings, setting variable "undefined" doesn't make any sense and can cause troubles while debugging because you break the meaning of undefined by this. If you want to follow JavaScript standard, don't ever set a variable to undefined, otherwise you are making your own standards and your code can behave unexpectedly for other programmers.

Awesome implementation, Adam! Thanks!

Hello,

I'm working on a project and have had this article open ever since I started because I think it's such a great idea! However as I'm going through the Maps API documentation, I've actually found another solution that doesn't require listening for clicks outside of the map dom element. The API actually has built-in event listeners that you can use to achieve the same effect (using the functions from your example):


function init(){
  map = new google.maps.Map(el[0], {
    zoom: 10,
    center: new google.maps.LatLng(47.49840560, 19.04075779),
    scrollwheel:  false
  });

  // Enable scrolling on click event on the map
  map.addListener('click', enableScrollingWithMouseWheel);

  // Enable scrolling on drag event on the map
  map.addListener('drag', enableScrollingWithMouseWheel);

  // Disable scrolling on mouseout from the map
  map.addListener('mouseout', disableScrollingWithMouseWheel);
}

Hope this helps someone!

Hey Milan, thanks for your kind words.

At AutoScout24 we use this approach and serve it for millions of users and I can assure you that we haven't really experienced any troubles with this icon solution. :)

Only one thing comes to my mind:
If you have a lot of complicated icons then the file size can grow. My solution was to defer the loading of the script in this case (use defer or async attribute on the script tag). This worked for me quite well, because we always had text next to the icons. So even in case the icons cannot load, the user still has some fallback content.

Besides that I really did not see any issues.

Hi Mohammed, you get the `options` passed to your helper by Handlebars itself. The two functions are the two generated template functions 

options.fn() // returns generated html for the positive case
options.inverse() // returns html for the else path

Please take a look at here for more details:
http://handlebarsjs.com/blo...

Hey Justin for this u need to add a custom css and java script code in addition to your basic html code

Html
<div class="embed-container maps">
<iframe *your_google_map_embed_code*="">
</iframe>
</div>
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
for css part :

//*dont change any of the code or class in html .maps is the default class for google maps*

.maps iframe{
pointer-events: none;
}

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
[Javascript]

var onMapMouseleaveHandler = function (event) {
var that = $(this);

that.on('click', onMapClickHandler);
that.off('mouseleave', onMapMouseleaveHandler);
that.find('iframe').css("pointer-events", "none");
}

var onMapClickHandler = function (event) {
var that = $(this);

that.off('click', onMapClickHandler);

that.find('iframe').css("pointer-events", "auto");

that.on('mouseleave', onMapMouseleaveHandler);
}

$('.maps.embed-container').on('click', onMapClickHandler);

------------------------
Note : make sure the theme you are using with wix doesn't have a custom jquery selector ... if they have a custom jquery selector to avoid any conflict modes you can just add the selector after every '$' symbol [ E.g: $p(this) ]
